what: Integrate OpenAI's Large Language Models Into Your R Workflows
title: Integrate OpenAI's Large Language Models Into Your R Workflows
text: Integrate OpenAI’s GPT models R workflows.

title: Integrate OpenAI's Large Language Models Into Your R Workflows
text: can install development version OpenAIR GitHub :

title: Integrate OpenAI's Large Language Models Into Your R Workflows
text: use package, ’ll need OpenAI API key. can sign API key . API key, can start using OpenAIR: , can start chatting model. simplest way interacting ChatGPT chat()-function. Using essentially interacting ChatGPT via web GUI (https://chat.openai.com/chat). chat() primarily useful interactive mode. writing short scripts developing functions based OpenAIR, infix function %c% provides alternative syntax send messages model indicate output format required.
code: # load the package library("OpenAIR")  # register your api key openai_api_key("YOUR-API-KEY"") # use chat() to interact with ChatGPT through the R console chat("Write a 100 words essay on why OpenAIR,  an R package to integrate GPT models into your R workflows is fantastic.  Write it in the style of product launches moderated by Steve Jobs.") Ladies and gentlemen, let me introduce you to OpenAIR, the latest and greatest addition to the R community. Thanks to OpenAIR, you can now integrate the cutting-edge GPT models right into your R workflows, unlocking a world of possibilities for predictive modeling and natural language processing. Whether you're an experienced data scientist or a newcomer to the field, OpenAIR makes it easier than ever to create powerful models that generate high-quality text. From business applications to academic research, OpenAIR has the power to transform the way we work with language data. So what are you waiting for? Join the excitement and embrace the future of data science with OpenAIR! chat("Now shorten the essay to 30 words.") OpenAIR - unleash the full power of GPT models in R workflows. # output to console "Remove all numeric characters from '5XC-2a09ujnap9o2q0MP'" %c%  "message_to_console" The string without numeric characters would be 'XC-aujnapqMP'. # return the message as a string resp <-  "Remove all numeric characters from '5XC-2a09ujnap9o2q0MP' In your response, only provide what remains from the string" %c% "message"   resp [1] "XC-aujnapoqMP"

what: Add data to a chat log — add_to_chatlog
title: Add data to a chat log — add_to_chatlog

title: Add data to a chat log — add_to_chatlog
Add data to a chat log — add_to_chatlog
text: msgs chatlog object data.frame containing messages added chat log. chatlog_id id chatlog object. Required provided msgs data.frame.

title: Add data to a chat log — add_to_chatlog
text: updated chatlog object newly added messages.

title: Add data to a chat log — add_to_chatlog
text: Ulrich Matter umatter@protonmail.com

title: Add data to a chat log — add_to_chatlog
code: if (FALSE) { # Add a data frame of messages to an existing chat log chatlog_df <- data.frame( user = c("user1", "user2"), message = c("Hello!", "Hi!") ) updated_chatlog <- add_to_chatlog(chatlog_df, "existing_chatlog_id")  # Add messages from one chat log to another chatlog1 <- create_chatlog("chatlog1") chatlog2 <- create_chatlog("chatlog2") chatlog1 <- add_message(chatlog1, "user1", "Hello!") chatlog2 <- add_message(chatlog2, "user2", "Hi!") merged_chatlog <- add_to_chatlog(chatlog1, chatlog2@chatlog_id) }

what: Start or continue a chat conversation — chat

text: function starts continues chat conversation adds user's message conversation. conversation exist, new one initiated.

title: Start or continue a chat conversation — chat
Start or continue a chat conversation — chat
text: message message added chat conversation chatlog_id ID chat conversation start continue. Default "__CURRENTCHAT__". output output format response. Default "message_to_console". Valid options "message_to_console", "message", "response_object".

title: Start or continue a chat conversation — chat
text: Depending value 'output' argument, function returns one following: * "message_to_console": message containing response text printed console. * "message": response text character vector. * "response_object": full response object ChatGPT API.

title: Start or continue a chat conversation — chat
text: Ulrich Matter umatter@protonmail.com

what: Generate Text Using the OpenAI API's Chat Endpoint — chat_completion
title: Generate Text Using the OpenAI API's Chat Endpoint — chat_completion
text: function generates natural language text conversational style using OpenAI API's chat endpoint. takes series chat messages input, either data.frame chatlog object, generates text completion based conversation history specified model parameters.

title: Generate Text Using the OpenAI API's Chat Endpoint — chat_completion
code: chat_completion(   msgs,   model = "gpt-3.5-turbo",   temperature = NULL,   max_tokens = NULL,   n = NULL,   stop = NULL,   presence_penalty = NULL,   frequency_penalty = NULL,   best_of = NULL,   logit_bias = NULL,   stream = FALSE,   top_p = NULL,   user = NULL )

title: Generate Text Using the OpenAI API's Chat Endpoint — chat_completion
text: msgs data.frame containing chat history generate text chatlog object. model character string specifying ID model use. default value "gpt-3.5-turbo". temperature optional numeric scalar specifying sampling temperature use. max_tokens optional integer scalar specifying maximum number tokens generate text. n optional integer scalar specifying number text completions generate. stop optional character string character vector specifying one stop sequences use generating text. presence_penalty optional numeric scalar specifying presence penalty use generating text. default value NULL. frequency_penalty optional numeric scalar specifying frequency penalty use generating text. default value NULL. best_of optional integer scalar specifying number completions generate return best one. default value NULL. logit_bias optional named numeric vector specifying logit bias use token generated text. stream optional logical scalar specifying whether use streaming API. default value FALSE. top_p optional numeric scalar specifying top p sampling ratio. default value NULL. user unique identifier representing end-user, can help OpenAI monitor detect abuse.

title: Generate Text Using the OpenAI API's Chat Endpoint — chat_completion
text: character vector containing generated text(s).

title: Generate Text Using the OpenAI API's Chat Endpoint — chat_completion
text: Ulrich Matter umatter@protonmail.com

title: Generate Text Using the OpenAI API's Chat Endpoint — chat_completion
code: if (FALSE) { openai_api_key("your_api_key_here") msgs_df <- data.frame(role=c("system", "user", "assistant", "user"), content=c("You are a helpful assistant", "Who won the world series in 2020?", "The Los Angeles Dodgers won the World Series in 2020.", "Where was it played?")) chat_completion(msgs_df) }

what: Check if a text file or character string contains an R function definition — contains_r_func

text: function parses text file character string returns TRUE contains valid R function definition. uses regex pattern identify possible R function definitions attempts parse matched lines R code.

title: Check if a text file or character string contains an R function definition — contains_r_func
Check if a text file or character string contains an R function definition — contains_r_func
text: input character string specifying path text file, character string containing text checked R function definition.

title: Check if a text file or character string contains an R function definition — contains_r_func
text: logical value (TRUE FALSE) indicating whether input   contains valid R function definition.

title: Check if a text file or character string contains an R function definition — contains_r_func
code: # Create a temporary file with an R function definition temp_file <- tempfile(fileext = ".R") writeLines("example_function <- function(x) {\n  return(x * 2)\n}", temp_file)  # Check if the temporary file contains an R function definition result <- contains_r_func(temp_file) print(result) # Should print TRUE #> [1] TRUE  # Check if a character string contains an R function definition result <- contains_r_func("example_function <- function(x) { return(x * 2) }") print(result) # Should print TRUE #> [1] TRUE  # Remove the temporary file file.remove(temp_file) #> [1] TRUE

title: Convert a data.frame to a CSV-formatted character string — df_to_csv
code: # Create a data.frame example_data <- data.frame(   Name = c("Alice", "Bob", "Carol"),   Age = c(30, 25, 28),   Height = c(168, 175, 162),   stringsAsFactors = FALSE )  # Convert the data.frame to a CSV-formatted character string csv_string <- df_to_csv(example_data) cat(csv_string) #> "Name","Age","Height" #> "Alice",30,168 #> "Bob",25,175 #> "Carol",28,162

Convert Python code to R code — python_to_r
text: py file path character string containing Python code converted.

title: Convert Python code to R code — python_to_r
text: input character string, function returns converted R code         character string. input file, function writes converted R code         new file name ".R" extension, returns output file path.

title: Convert Python code to R code — python_to_r
code: if (FALSE) { # Convert a Python code string to R code python_code <- "x = 5" r_code <- python_to_r(python_code) print(r_code)  # Convert a Python code file to an R code file python_file <- "path/to/your/python_file.py" r_file <- python_to_r(python_file) cat(readLines(r_file), sep = "\n") }

title: Convert Text to Tidy-Text Format — read_text

title: Convert Text to Tidy-Text Format — read_text
code: read_text("Hello, how are you?") #> # A tibble: 1 × 4 #>   text                file              line batch_index #>   <chr>               <chr>            <int>       <dbl> #> 1 Hello, how are you? character string     1           1 read_text("path/to/text/file.txt") #> # A tibble: 1 × 4 #>   text                  file              line batch_index #>   <chr>                 <chr>            <int>       <dbl> #> 1 path/to/text/file.txt character string     1           1

what: Regenerate the last response in an ongoing chat — regenerate
title: Regenerate the last response in an ongoing chat — regenerate
text: function removes last response chatlog, generates new response based updated chatlog, updates chatlog accordingly. output can displayed message console, returned message, returned response object.

title: Regenerate the last response in an ongoing chat — regenerate
Regenerate the last response in an ongoing chat — regenerate
text: chatlog_id character string specifying ID chatlog (default: '.__CURRENTCHAT__') output character string specifying output format. Options 'message_to_console', 'message', 'response_object' (default: 'message_to_console')

title: Regenerate the last response in an ongoing chat — regenerate
text: output 'message_to_console', function returns NULL prints message console.         output 'message', function returns character string containing message.         output 'response_object', function returns full response object.

title: Regenerate the last response in an ongoing chat — regenerate
code: if (FALSE) { # Start a new chat and save the chatlog ID chatlog_id <- chat("Hello, how are you?")  # Regenerate the last response in the chat and display it in the console regenerate(chatlog_id)  # Regenerate the last response in the chat and return it as a message message <- regenerate(chatlog_id, output = "message") print(message)  # Regenerate the last response in the chat and return it as a response object response_object <- regenerate(chatlog_id, output = "response_object") print(response_object) }

title: Replace File Extension — replace_file_extension

text: filename input filename character string. new_extension new file extension replace old one (including dot, e.g., ".bib").

title: Replace File Extension — replace_file_extension
text: character string representing filename replaced file extension.

title: Replace File Extension — replace_file_extension
text: Ulrich Matter umatter@protonmail.com

title: Replace File Extension — replace_file_extension
code: if (FALSE) { # Replace the file extension of a text file with a BibTeX extension new_filename <- replace_file_extension("example_document.txt", ".bib") print(new_filename) # "example_document.bib" }

what: Set up a new chatlog — set_chatlog
title: Set up a new chatlog — set_chatlog
text: function sets new chatlog object conversation.

title: Set up a new chatlog — set_chatlog
code: set_chatlog(   initial_role = "system",   initial_content = "You are a helpful assistant.",   chatlog_id = NULL )

title: Set up a new chatlog — set_chatlog
text: initial_role character string representing role issueing initial content (per default: "system") initial_content character string representing initial message system chatlog_id character string representing ID conversation. Per default, set automatically.

title: Set up a new chatlog — set_chatlog
text: new chatlog object

title: Set up a new chatlog — set_chatlog
code: chat <- set_chatlog("Welcome to our chat!") is_chatlog(chat) #> [1] TRUE chat #> An object of class "chatlog" #> Slot "messages": #>                   role                      content #> 1 Welcome to our chat! You are a helpful assistant. #>  #> Slot "chatlog_id": #> [1] ".chatlog_20230330164148" #>

what: Start a new chat session — start_chat
title: Start a new chat session — start_chat
text: function starts new chat session initializing messages object initial system message, creating new log environment store messages, adding messages object log environment.

title: Start a new chat session — start_chat
code: start_chat(   initial_role = "system",   initial_content = "You are a helpful assistant.",   show = FALSE,   chatlog_id = NULL )

title: Start a new chat session — start_chat
text: initial_role character string representing role issueing initial content (per default: "system") initial_content character string representing initial message system show Logical, TRUE, current chat log displayed via View(). Default FALSE. chatlog_id character string representing ID conversation. Per default, set automatically.

title: Start a new chat session — start_chat
text: character string indicating name log environment created chat session.

title: Start a new chat session — start_chat
code: # Start a new chat session with the default system message chatlog_id <- start_chat()  # Start a new chat session with a custom system message chatlog_id <- start_chat("How can I assist you today?")
